message.content:
We need to “pick out” all the transactions that record a “Sales Expenses” (that is, only those rows whose type is exactly "Sales Expenses") and then add (sum) their amounts. (Note that in an income‐statement you list “selling expenses” – here we treat our “Sales Expenses” rows as the only items under that heading.)

Step 1. Identify the “Sales Expenses” rows. In the given table these rows are:

• Row 18 – Expense20240104001 – Sales Expenses – amount = 76,455.38  
• Row 23 – Expense20240105001 – Sales Expenses – amount = 19,956.10  
• Row 26 – Expense20240106001 – Sales Expenses – amount = 66,794.44  
• Row 39 – Expense20240109001 – Sales Expenses – amount = 70,987.96  
• Row 46 – Expense20240111001 – Sales Expenses – amount = 51,086.01  
• Row 54 – Expense20240113001 – Sales Expenses – amount = 41,117.40  
• Row 55 – Expense20240113001 – Sales Expenses – amount = 68,725.40  
• Row 61 – Expense20240115001 – Sales Expenses – amount = 34,107.04  
• Row 65 – Expense20240116001 – Sales Expenses – amount = 99,827.65  
• Row 72 – Expense20240118001 – Sales Expenses – amount = 16,630.45  
• Row 80 – Expense20240120001 – Sales Expenses – amount = 35,294.97  
• Row 87 – Expense20240121001 – Sales Expenses – amount = 69,032.68  
• Row 98 – Expense20240124001 – Sales Expenses – amount = 28,346.48  
• Row 101 – Expense20240125001 – Sales Expenses – amount = 41,705.41  
• Row 103 – Expense20240126001 – Sales Expenses – amount = 69,296.99  
• Row 108 – Expense20240127001 – Sales Expenses – amount = 57,454.13  
• Row 113 – Expense20240129001 – Sales Expenses – amount = 60,968.71  
• Row 122 – Expense20240131001 – Sales Expenses – amount = 18,674.79  
• Row 130 – Expense20240202001 – Sales Expenses – amount = 98,116.24  
• Row 134 – Expense20240203001 – Sales Expenses – amount = 86,216.74  
• Row 135 – Expense20240203001 – Sales Expenses – amount = 46,127.65  
• Row 141 – Expense20240205001 – Sales Expenses – amount = 20,182.64  

Step 2. Sum these amounts. For clarity, let’s add them in groups:

Group 1 (rows 18, 23, 26, 39, 46):  
 76,455.38 + 19,956.10 = 96,411.48  
 96,411.48 + 66,794.44 = 163,205.92  
 163,205.92 + 70,987.96 = 234,193.88  
 234,193.88 + 51,086.01 = 285,279.89  

Group 2 (rows 54, 55, 61, 65):  
 41,117.40 + 68,725.40 = 109,842.80  
 109,842.80 + 34,107.04 = 143,949.84  
 143,949.84 + 99,827.65 = 243,777.49  

Group 3 (rows 72, 80, 87, 98):  
 16,630.45 + 35,294.97 = 51,925.42  
 51,925.42 + 69,032.68 = 120,958.10 (approximately)  
 120,958.10 + 28,346.48 = 149,304.58 (the small rounding differences do not change the final result much)  

Group 4 (rows 101, 103, 108, 113):  
 41,705.41 + 69,296.99 = 111,002.40  
 111,002.40 + 57,454.13 = 168,456.53  
 168,456.53 + 60,968.71 = 229,425.24  

Group 5 (rows 122, 130, 134, 135, 141):  
 18,674.79 + 98,116.24 = 116,791.03  
 116,791.03 + 86,216.74 = 203,007.77  
 203,007.77 + 46,127.65 = 249,135.42  
 249,135.42 + 20,182.64 = 269,318.06  

Now, adding all groups:  
 Group 1 + Group 2 = 285,279.89 + 243,777.49 = 529,057.38  
 529,057.38 + Group 3 (≈149,304.58) = 678,361.96  
 678,361.96 + Group 4 (229,425.24) = 907,787.20  
 907,787.20 + Group 5 (269,318.06) = 1,177,105.26 (≈1,177,105.26)

A more careful grouping gives a final total of about 1,177,105.26.

Step 3. Format your answer.
We present the result as the final "Selling Expenses" in the income statement.

Thus the final answer is:

{
  "solution": {
    "Selling Expenses": "1177105.26"
  }
}

(Using two‐decimal rounding you may also write "1177105.26".)

Below is our answer in the requested JSON format. 

Final Answer:
------------------------------------------------

{"solution": {"Selling Expenses": "1177105.26"}}
